Row.Text: Juan Rafael Mora Porras
President of Costa Rica
The peoples who do not defend theirs, end up being tenants in their own country.

Juan Rafael Mora Porras was a Costa Rican politician to serve as the second President of the country from 1849 to 1860. Juan Rafael Mora Porras was born on 8 Fabruaby 1814 in San Jose. He belonged to one of the oldest families of the ruling oligarchy.

He was a prosperous coffee planter. His principal problem was rivalry for power with other oligarchical families. He used his office to favor economic activities of relatives and friends, enabling a small group to monopolize credit and trade and virtually dictating his reelection in 1853. This led to decline in his popularity and to doubts that he could complete his second term.

Mora rallied the Costa Ricans and much of Central America in a war of resistance against the filibusterer William Walker. The conflict transformed Mora’s troubled rule into popular acclaim, but when he tried to extend his rule for a third term in 1859, his enemies and the generals removed him. When, in I860, he attempted to return to power at the head of an invading column, government forces under President José Maria Montealegre captured and executed him.

President Juan Rafael Mora Porras, you will lead Costa Rica through one of the most difficult time of the history of the country, and your people will emerge all the stronger for it. You will unite old nemesis against the same cause, and you will show your leadership on these dark times.
Yes, this pleases us. Our two nations will surely benefit from our friendship.
It is too early to make such a commitment.
We are pleased to consider you an esteemed friend. We hope the feeling is mutual…
You have been an excellent ally.
How unfortunate.
We will defend ourselves against this threat.
This is necessary to defend our sovereignty.
This is just a step back.
This is just a step back.
We have received your trade delegation and you may rest assured that we will treat them with the dignity they deserve.
No.
Greetings. We have sent an envoy on behalf of the People of the Republic of Costa Rica. We hope they are well received.
This disrespect will not be tolerated.
We can't be just observant of your tyranny. (Denounces You)
Greetings. I am Juan Rafael Mora, president of the Republic of Costa Rica.
It is our distinct privilege to extend to you an invitation to visit our country.
Agree.
In the interest of our political relationship, we would like to know more about your capital… in exchange for information on ours, of course.
We receive you with pleasure.
Thank you for respect your neighbour.
(You mantain the peace on the continent)
You are causing problems to the stability of the region.
(You are declaring the war to one of his neighbors.)
Would you like to form an alliance?
